intro: Carex stolonifera subsp. vulgaris, commonly known as the common sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its triangular, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikes. The plant spreads via stolons, forming dense mats that can colonize wet or moist soils. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and is often found in wetlands, marshes, and along stream banks. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for various invertebrates and birds.
